Hello, I am an automated registration bot. I help manage the registration process by checking your registration against a set of [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). If all these guidelines are met, this pull request will be merged automatically, completing your registration. It is **strongly recommended** to follow the guidelines, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

## 1. New package registration

Please make sure that you have read the [package naming guidelines](https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1).

## 2. [AutoMerge Guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/) are all met! âœ…

Your new package registration met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

## 3. To pause or stop registration

If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.

_Tip: You can edit blocking comments to add `[noblock]` in order to unblock auto-merging._

<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

[noblock] I didn't think that SLH stood for "System Level Hamiltonian", does it? Wondering if it might be more recognizable to keep `SLH` as an acronym as part of the name. Something like `QuantumSLH`, `QuantumNetworkSLH`, `QuantumOpticsSLH`, or something along those linesâ€¦

[noblock] That's right, I made up the name as a backronym for SLH and a reference to the linear control technique [system-level synthesis](https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.01634). I would be happy to name the package SLH.jl, but read somewhere that short acronym names are discouraged. I can add an explanation about the name to the readme

[noblock] Yeah, just `SLH.jl` isn't going to be a possibility, but combining the "acronym" `SLH` with something that gives it context would be totally fine. It's up to you, though. But when I first saw just the name `SystemLevelHamiltonian` I definitely didn't make the connection, and just thought "that's a weird name". Of course, when I saw "SLH", I got pretty excited, since back in the day I worked on [QNET](https://github.com/mabuchilab/QNET) for a whileâ€¦ ðŸ˜‰

There _is_ some value in the recognizability of acronyms that gets lost when trying to write it out in a package name. But just `SLH` by itself doesn't mean anything to the broad audience of `General`, which is why we have a pretty hard "minimum length 5 letters rule" and a less hard "no-all-caps rule".

[noblock] SLH in Julia, love to see it! But I agree that system-level Hamiltonian is a confusing backronym, not least because an SLH triple doesn't generally describe unitary dynamics. If I stumbled over SystemLevelHamiltonian.jl while searching for a package for doing SLH algebra, I might just dismiss it and keep scrolling without taking a closer look. QuantumSLH.jl looks great to me, and also maximizes discoverability---I imagine the most likely search query for someone looking for a package like this would be "SLH quantum julia".

Ok, I am going to change the name. Currently I am thinking SLHQuantumSystems. What is the best way to proceed, simply close this PR and make a new one once I have changed the name of the package and github repo?

See [the FAQ "What to do when asked to reconsider/update the package name?"](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General?tab=readme-ov-file#what-to-do-when-asked-to-reconsiderupdate-the-package-name)

You just rename the repo, change the name _inside_ the repo, and then make a new registration. Then we can close this PR in favor of the new one.
This can be closed in favor of https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/135303
